abstract.text: A user interface element that contains and displays text, scroll, and browser views, in addition to other view subclasses.

inlineContent.text: Drawers are deprecated and should not be used in modern macOS apps.

platforms.message: Drawers are deprecated; consider using NSSplitViewController
platforms.name: macOS

inlineContent.text: A drawer is associated with a window, called its parent, and can appear only while its parent is visible onscreen. A drawer cannot be moved or ordered independently of a window, but is instead attached to one edge of its parent and moves along with it.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
An object that stores image data in a form that can be readily transferred to the screen.
A user interface element that contains and displays text, scroll, and browser views, in addition to other view subclasses.
These constants specify the possible states of a drawer.
If the receiver is open, this method closes it.
An action method to close the receiver.
The size of the receiver’s content area.
The receiver’s content view.
The receiver’s delegate.
Posted whenever the drawer is closed.
Posted whenever the drawer is opened.
The edge of the window that the receiver is connected to.
Creates a new drawer with the given size on the specified edge of the parent window.
The receiver’s leading offset.
The maximum allowed size of the receiver’s content area.
The minimum allowed size of the receiver’s content area.
If the receiver is closed, this method opens it.
An action method to open the drawer.
Causes the receiver to open on the specified edge of the parent window.
The receiver’s parent window.
The receiver’s preferred, or default, edge.
The state of the receiver.
Toggles the drawer open or closed.
The receiver’s trailing offset.
Posted whenever the drawer is about to close.
Posted whenever the drawer is about to open.
An
object is a vertical matrix of
objects to implement the fields.
The
class is used to implement text entry fields in a form. The left part of an
object contains a title. The right part contains an editable text entry field.
An object that handles the measurement and display of a single menu item in its encompassing frame.
An object that represents an OpenGL graphics context, into which all OpenGL calls are rendered.
A subclass of
that is suitable for rendering OpenGL into layers.
An object that provides access to accelerated offscreen rendering.
An object that specifies the types of buffers and other attributes of the OpenGL context.
A view that displays OpenGL content in a view.
An abstract class that forms the basis of event and command processing in AppKit.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A layer that provides a layer suitable for rendering OpenGL content.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
